Stanley G. Feldman. an attor-
ney from Tucson, and DR.. Nor
rison Warren, a school principal
in Phoenix participated in ma
tional conference of State Advis-
DRY ommittee held at the Sher-
aton-Park Hotel June d and %.
The commission announced plans
to proceed with implementation
of the new clearing house func-
ton assigned to the Commission
in the 1864 Civil Rights Bill.
as soon as the bill is signed.


Over $50 delegates from so
states and the District Of Col
umbia participated in the map
ping of plans for providing civil
rights Information and assistance
to Federal, State, and local Of
ficials and community groups en-
gagged in carrying out the OBJ
jectives of the new legislation.


John A. Hannah, chairman Of
the Commission, reminded the
delegates that the late President
John F. Kennedy. in proposing the
clearing house function, had
stressed the value of the "ex-
perience and capability' Of the
Civil Rights Commission in con-
tributing to public knowledge and
creating 1.-THE atmosphere of un-
derstanding which is indispen-
sable to peaceful and permanent
solutions to racial problems"

z krizonuns Attend
Rights Meet In DC.

SAN FRANC1SCO--Frank L.
Stanley, Sr., publisher Of the
Louisville. (Ky.) Defender, was
elected president Of the National
Newspaper Publishers Associa-
ton at its annual 24th convention.
He previously served as presi-
dent from l945-48.


In 1916 he was named as chair
man of the first group Of Ameri-
can journalists commissioned to
study race relations among US.
troops in Europe.


In 1855 and 1857 he served as
national president of the Alpha
Phi Alpha fraternity.


During 1862. Mr.. Stanley, was
one of a four man team who taught
journalism for the state depart
ment in six African nations.


Since completing his teaching
abroad, he has been consultant
on state personnel, and serves as
a member Of the Kentucky COM
mission on civil rights.


His newspaper Is rated as one
Of the best Negro owned news
papers and It has won 81 national
honors, including the Wilkie and
Russwrm Awards.


NNPA will hold its 18th annual
convention in Louisville, in June,
1865.

AS the family moves outdoors
with the summer weather, you'll
be thinking of new treats to serve
them. For a tray of cold snacks,
spread slices Of salami with pre-
pared roquefort-blue cheese
spread. Add few sprigs of wa
tercress. Roll jelly-roll fashion
and chill. Just before you serve
them, cut in bite-size pieces and
serve on toothpicks. They taste
good with crisp sesame crackers.

fond farewell the home MIR. and
Banks 237 E. Broadway Rd They babe farewell
Mrs. Robert Bowman, who left Williams Air Force
Calf Dr. Bowman will intern
at San Jose County Hospital.


From Capt. Jenkins, USAF, Capt Bowman,
Mrs. Herbert Williams and Mrs. Bowman, seated.
